Award.AwardTitle: Field and Laboratory Study of Rural Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) Oxidation and Secondary Organic Aerosol (SOA) Formation Utilizing Measurements of Formaldehyde and Glyoxal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aerosol and ozone (O3) affect human health, the environment, and climate. Oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), in particular via the hydroxyl radical (OH), is directly coupled to the formation of O3 and it contributes to secondary organic aerosol (SOA), an important component of ambient aerosol. As part of the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS) the principal investigators (PIs) planned comprehensive laboratory and field studies focused on improving the detailed mechanistic understanding of the processes controlling OH and isoprene, the most important VOC, especially in rural environments. A goal is to specifically study the anthropogenic impact on biogenic VOC (BVOC) oxidation and resulting SOA formation. The project addresses the following questions: 1) How well do current mechanisms represent VOC oxidation, especially for isoprene, and in particular under low-NO conditions? 2) How well do current mechanisms/models represent OH photochemistry in view of recent findings of potential measurement interferences? 3) What are the dominant mechanisms of anthropogenic influence on rural VOC oxidation and resulting O3 and SOA formation?

This research is designed to contribute ultimately to improved prediction of secondary pollutant effects from precursor emissions, and an improved ability to mitigate the anthropogenic effects of emissions on climate, human health, and the environment. The PIs also will develop a Library of Organic Standards for Atmospheric Chemistry (OSAC) that will be a publicly available online database aimed at enabling improved access to starting materials for laboratory studies and standards for calibrations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main results of this work are a significant improvement of reactions and chemical compounds in the pre-industrial atmosphere, which is helpful for understanding how anthropogenic influence has changed key reaction pathways and the types of molecules in the atmosphere. This work conducted a comprehensive study of the formation, reactions and properties of organic hydroperoxides, the main class of compounds formed from the oxidation of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) under preindustrial conditions. VOC oxidation is directly coupled to the formation of ozone and secondary organic aerosol (SOA), which affect human health and climate. Thus, the improved understanding of organic hydroperoxides is important for understanding the differences in ozone and SOA and its impact between preindustrial and modern conditions. 

 

Specifically, we conducted a comprehensive, collaborative study of the role and properties of isoprene hydroxy hydroperoxides (ISOPOOH) formed via oxidation of isoprene, a reactive, biogenic VOC with the highest emissions globally. The grant has resulted in a comprehensive study of the gas-phase source and fate of ISOPOOH, quantification of its partitioning to aqueous systems, reactive fate in cloud droplets, potentially representing new formation pathway for SOA, interaction with plant as well as laboratory/instrumentation surfaces, as well as an ongoing study (not funded but enabled by this grant) on biological interactions. Only the work on interaction with plants and biological systems is not completed. Overall this represents a transformation in our understanding of the main reaction products under pre-industrial conditions.

In addition, work was conducted on improving our understanding of the formation of glyoxal and formaldehyde with implications form isoprene, as a function of anthropogenic influence, which has implications on their use as tracers of oxidative chemistry, inferring isoprene emission strengths, and the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) from glyoxal.
